Message.Title: $17 to $18 is the whisper number
Message.Msg: it is evident the "dissident" shareholders were not looking for a 50 cent sweetened offer over the $14.50 rumor, so obviously we are looking at $17 min with $18 to $19 possible in the "GO SHOP" bidding war. Shorts seem quite desperate, they should help the stock up another buck once the offer is put on the table, cause then its open season for DELL and $20 to $25 can easily happen as things get out of hand in this CRITICAL war for control of hardware of which there are only 3 pieces: mac, pc and mobile. WHATS 1/3 of the WORLDS computer hardware worth??? $20 billion, 30 billion??? errrrr. try something with the word TRILLION in it, see m.dell is not an idiot he knows where this is heading. deal or not, DELL will be taken to $30 which is why its going private, but either way this is on a trajectory to $30, but we will likely be forced to sell at $17, not such a great deal if we put it this way huh.

Message.Title: Go-shop period has begun, the deal is good to go!
Message.Msg: Founder and Chief executive Michael Dell, who holds a 16 percent stake in the computer company, has already given his backing to the buyout proposal made by the private equity firm. Now, the “go-shop” period has begun, which allows Dell to look for offers from other companies to guarantee it has agreed to the best possible proposal.

Topic.Title: Options Market Suggests Deal Price 13.50-14

Message.Msg: The options market is just following the rumor price between 13.5 and 14.5 as was reported on cnbc. It's a lagging indicator in this case. also, the contracts might have been filled with sell-to-open, that info is not disclosed. Moreover, you don't know if the contract was filled as a covered hedge or uncovered long or short. We can only guess.

Topic.Title: Reliable source?

Message.Msg: No one directly involved has made any statement regarding a possible LBO of Dell. At this point I estimate there is a 50-50 chance of a deal happening and the price could be anywhere from $12 to $14 or more per share.

Topic.Title: Reliable source?

Message.Msg: "By keeping out of arranging the $15 billion financing for the deal, J.P. Morgan and Dell (Nasdaq: DELL) will avoid problems that arise when a bank advising a seller also helps provide financing for the buyers, The Wall Street Journal reports."
